race.name: SEVEN
race.tagline: Australia's crown jewel gravel race. 125km through Western Australia's forests. Host of 2026 UCI Gravel World Championships.

climate.primary: Australian autumnâ€”cool mornings, mild days, rain possible
climate.description: May is autumn in the Southern Hemisphere. Mornings start cold (7-9Â°C / 45-48Â°F), warming to comfortable 18-22Â°C (64-72Â°F). Nannup receives ~600mm rain annually and May is the start of the wetter season. 2024 saw rain the day before that 'settled the dust' but heavy rain can make descents treacherous.
challenges: Rain risk in early wet season

terrain.primary: Narrow parallel singletrack through pine plantations and state forests
terrain.surface: 96% unpavedâ€”quartz grit, mica, and clay base. Sharp rocks slice thin sidewalls.

gravel_god_rating.tier_override_reason: Prestige 5 + score >= 75 â€” promoted to Tier 1

prestige.explanation: UCI Gravel World Series qualifier and HOST of 2026 UCI Gravel World Championships. Largest gravel race in the Southern Hemisphere. The event that put Australian gravel on the global map.

race_quality.explanation: Well-organized with official Survival Guide, moto marshals, and sweepers. UCI-standard timing and categories. The remote sectors require self-sufficiency but support infrastructure is solid.

experience.explanation: Unique adventureâ€”riding through pine plantations on parallel singletrack, navigating wildlife, conquering The Crucible. The scenery is unexpectedly beautiful (not red desert). Riders describe it as 'going to hell and back.'

community.explanation: Growing Australian gravel community centered on this event. International riders increasingly making the trek. The shared challenge of the technical terrain creates camaraderie.

field_depth.explanation: UCI World Series status attracts international elite gravel racers. Strong Australian domestic field. The 2026 Worlds hosting will only increase competition level. Deeper field than most â€” comparable to Badlands.

value.explanation: ~AUD $200-250 is reasonable for a UCI-level event. The real cost is getting to Western Australiaâ€”flights from Europe/US are expensive and time-consuming.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs AUD $200-$250. Major travel commitment for most international riders. Perth flights, rental car, accommodation in a tiny town that books out. Budget for a multi-day adventure, not a quick race trip. Higher total cost than Badlands.

logistics.explanation: Fly into Perth, drive 3 hours south to a town of 1,300 people where accommodation sells out instantly. You'll need a rental car because public transport to Nannup doesn't exist for cyclists with bike boxes. The saving grace is camping at the event village, which is the authentic way anyway, and Margaret River is only 45 minutes if you need actual beds.

length.explanation: 78 miles sounds reasonable until you realize it's 3,200m of climbing through pine plantations on parallel singletrack. This isn't a distance gameâ€”it's a suffering-per-kilometer optimization problem. The mileage is modest but the terrain makes it feel twice as long. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: These aren't wide gravel highwaysâ€”they're essentially two tire tracks through state forests with sharp quartz grit that slices thin sidewalls. The Crucible hits 20% gradients on loose surface, and the parallel singletrack means constant line choice through narrow, winding sectors. You need reinforced sidewalls and actual bike handling skills, not just fitness. More technical than most â€” comparable to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego. As Surface Description puts it: "The 2026 route has no single track and no fire trails. All the roads used in SEVEN are unpaved and well-formed with a mix of dirt, gravel, hard-packed clay, quartz grit and mica."

elevation.explanation: 10,500 feet in 78 miles is a climber's nightmare with 12-13 categorized climbs including The Crucible's 20% gradients. The climbing ratio here rivals rigorous mountain stages, which is why everyone runs mullet drivetrains with 50-52t granny gears. Standard 1:1 ratios leave mortals walking. Among the hilliest in gravel, comparable to Badlands. As Climbs puts it: "Ten major climbs of SEVEN are amongst the best that the State has to offer. These climbs range in length from 1.2km to 4.5km long with gradients frequently touching on 20%."

climate.explanation: Australian autumn means cool 45Â°F mornings warming to pleasant 70Â°F daysâ€”no outback furnace here. May marks the start of wet season with 600mm annual rainfall, so rain can turn clay sections slick and make descents sketchy. It's actually civilized weather, which is probably why this race attracts 1,500 masochists. Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL.

altitude.explanation: Nannup sits in Western Australia's coastal forests, not the mountains. You're dealing with rolling terrain through pine plantations and state forests, so oxygen isn't your enemy here. The elevation gain comes from constant undulations, not thin air. Modest altitude compared to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

adventure.explanation: The official survival guide warns about kangaroo, emu, and wild pig collisions on silent descents through active logging areas with zero cell signal. You're reliant on moto marshals in wilderness where wildlife can end your race violently. This is proper adventure cycling with real consequences, not manicured gravel theater.

biased_opinion.summary: SEVEN is Australia's answer to the world's great gravel racesâ€”and in 2026, it will literally host the World Championships. The 125km course through Western Australian forests is brutally technical with 3,200m of climbing on sharp quartz gravel. The Crucible alone, with 20%+ grades on loose surface, separates this from smooth US gravel. It's a genuine adventure race in a location that surprises everyone who expected red desert.
strengths: Largest gravel race in Southern Hemisphere
weaknesses: Remote location requires major travel commitment
biased_opinion.bottom_line: If you can make the trek to Western Australia, SEVEN delivers a world-class gravel experience unlike anything else.

final_verdict.one_liner: Australia's crown jewelâ€”hosting 2026 Worlds with brutal climbs, wildlife hazards, and Western Australian wilderness.
final_verdict.should_you_race: Yes if you want a bucket-list Australian adventure and handle technical terrain. Yes if you're chasing UCI Gravel World Series. Skip if the travel commitment to Western Australia is prohibitive.
final_verdict.alternatives: The Traka 360 (Europe's equivalent ultra); Crusher in the Tushar (similar climbing ratio); Leadville 100 (altitude challenge)

logistics.lodging_strategy: Nannup (pop. 1,300) accommodation sells out instantly. Most stay in Busselton or Margaret River (45min). Event village offers unpowered camping/caravan sitesâ€”the 'authentic' experience. Rental car essential.
logistics.food: Limited options in Nannup. Stock up before arriving.
logistics.packet_pickup: Race week at event village in Nannup.

history.origin_story: Created to showcase Western Australia's incredible gravel terrain through the 'Golden Triangle' of forestry. Quickly became the largest gravel race in the Southern Hemisphere and earned UCI Gravel World Series status.
notable_moments: Secured 2026 UCI Gravel World Championships hosting
Grew to 1,500+ ridersâ€”largest in Southern Hemisphere
Part of UCI Gravel World Series qualifier system
history.reputation: The World Championship hostâ€”where Australian wilderness meets elite gravel racing.

course_description.character: A relentless climbing race through Western Australian pine plantations and state forests. The 'parallel singletrack' roads are often just two tire tracks wide with grass in the middle. Sharp quartz grit and mica create constant flat tire risk. 12-13 categorized climbs with 3,200m total elevation in 125kmâ€”one of the highest climbing ratios in gravel racing.

suffering_zones.label: Brockman Farm
suffering_zones.desc: Early significant climb. Tests legs before they're warm. Sets the tone for what's coming.

suffering_zones.label: The Crucible
suffering_zones.desc: Signature climb. Steep, loose, relentless. Gradients touch 20%+. 'Iconic gravel ride'â€”many walk sections.

suffering_zones.label: Chainsaw Ridge
suffering_zones.desc: Sector 5. Ridge-line traverse that exposes you to wind and fatigue late in the race.

suffering_zones.label: Arcadia
suffering_zones.desc: Beautiful but energy-sapping due to constant undulations. The quiet killer.

course_description.signature_challenge: The Crucibleâ€”the 20%+ grade climb on loose surface where 'I went to hell and back... gradients frequently touching 20%' is the common refrain.

citations.label: ucigravelworldseries.com: National Champions Show Power On 2026 Worlds Courses
lifeinthesaddle.cc: Race Report Seven Hills Killer 2012.Html

2024.conditions: Rain Risk: Nannup receives ~600mm rain annually

primary.name: Schwalbe G-One Ultrabite
primary.why: high puncture protection for sharp surfaces. strong mud clearance

videos.title: SEVEN 2025  | World Championship worthy?
videos.description:
Join Coach Michelle and Jenna as they tackle the 2026 gravel world championship course held in Nannup in Western Australia.

Need a coach? Contact us on the email below:
coaching@pedalaction.com.au

Training Plans: https://www.pedalaction.com.au/trainingplans

0:00 Introduction
1:25 Race start
2:44 Brockmans
3:29 Picking lines
4:10 Aid stations
5:03 Happy climbing
6:23 Descending
7:31 Elite riders
8:23 Ridge line
9:14 Single track & finish
9:43 Do it again?
10:22 World hamps

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/pedalaction.au
Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/pedal.actioncoaching/
Strava: https://www.strava.com/athletes/mcrick
videos.transcript:

Welcome to Nanab in Western Australia
for seven, the biggest gravel race in
the Southern Hemisphere. There are over
1,600 people registered for the race
tomorrow, principally because next year
this will hold the world championships.

Seven, which is 125 km with 3,200 meters
of climbing. Five, which is 85 km and
nearly 2,000 m of climbing. And then you
have three at 47 km and 1,25 m of
climbing. And one, which is 27 km with
nearly 500 m of climbing.
So once again, I've brought Jenna along.
Why did you want to come with me this

And it's going to be a really awesome

Today was the goal was to ride well, not

much better than I expected. I thought
there I wasn't going to get up a 22%
climb.
Woohoo. So, how is Broman, Jenna? It
looks like you're eating right now.
That was good. Yeah. Pretty. Dropped a
marbar. Dropped a marbar. Lost my lip
balm. Had to rescue that. Best stop for
the Mars bar. Yeah.
But the surfaces going down were
particularly sketchy. The gravel was
really, really loose. Yeah. Really
loose. And it will just dry, which I
guess makes it loose. Yeah.
I'm learning to pick a line and stick
with it. Y cuz there were a few times
that I felt a bit out of my comfort
zone, but I was like, well, if I just go
straight, I'll be fine. Mhm. Except when
there was like a right hand turn and
you're like you're like
Yeah.
I don't generally like to stop very
often when I'm riding because the
stopping time is what makes the ride
time longer. But I needed to go for a
wee at the top of Lake Crucible Crucible
and there was no port so I had to go
bushwe. So I went almost halfway. Yeah.
Pretty good. just under. Mhm. Actually,
a bish
bushwe in problems. What's that for? I
never need a wee. I needed a wei today.
Um
um and I think actually that worked out
quite well. I think doing it earlier and
then we just kept going further in the
track. We didn't need to stop at the
main stop at Lana Cottages, but it was
good to see so many people there.
Where's the elite feed?
You said before that you were happiest
climbing. Correct. I did say that at one
point. Yes.
Can you remember what the constant
climbs felt like? You don't get much
rest in the downhill, do you? Cuz you've
got to really concentrate. Yeah. Yeah.
But then you've got to go from one climb
to another climb to another climb. And
some of the climbs aren't even
classified on as a climb. Yeah. I think
what I meant by that
was that I feel in control. Yep. When
I'm climbing and in that I can sit into
a pace. Well, when you're not slipping
against your wheel, I feel in control
going uphill cuz I'm not going to
outspeed myself. That's for sure.
Whereas going downhill, I'm not a very
confident descender because of the dry
conditions and loose gravel. I just feel
less in control.
Is this where we walk? Yeah. Oh,
actually those speed bumps were fun. Oh,
those speed bumps were I I didn't enjoy
those. I mean, I'm glad we knew they
like I was like, "Oh, that's 53ks."
Yeah. And then I was like, "Oh, there
was a caution." Yeah. Yeah. I enjoyed
them knowing what they were once we got
there. Yeah. Yeah.
I enjoy the descending. I'm feel like
I'm getting a little bit better, but I
feel more in control, I think. Yeah. The
more you do the descents here on the
loose stuff, it comes back to like, you
know, like, oh, actually, I know it's
going to be really loose. There's a
corner coming up. Slow down. Whereas
normally, if it was a bit grippier,
you'd be able to go a little bit faster.
Yeah. Yeah, cuz some of those right hand
turns or left hand turns, whatever they
were, you like a few of them coming
almost to a dead stop before turning,
just waves of pebbles.
No, now I'm smiling and it's not
real. Out of the climbs we did do,
Brockman's will always be my favorite. I
love broccolins. I think the sun like
like the time of day just makes it
stunning.
Can you remember any of the clampers

We have just over 20k left to go.
Some of the elite riders were coming
through, so we had to make sure we stay
on the left. Come on,
Tiff. Come on, Talia. We don't
necessarily want to be on the left, but
picking your line through those sections
was I think it was all right cuz there
wasn't many people, but you do have to
be careful there.
I really want to be able to do this. I
don't I hate getting off and
particularly when it's not steep. It was
just so so loose. And then I had to run
and then the guy behind me I was like I
come stop paying and he's like oh good I
can get off as well cuz he was

was a particularly bad
one. And then we did the ridge line as
we came back down towards Waverly Bridge
the sharp right to the really last
descent. Oh, like with the grass like
the last 10k caves. Yeah. Yeah. Yeah.
That was beautiful. Like that's where
it's got green like greener again
like greeny pastures and stuff and then
that was that really sketchy descent but
yeah it was pretty loose and then we
crossed Wavely Bridge and then we're
back onto the stuff we tested yesterday
and it was just home run then. Yeah. And
I felt really comfortable on that cuz
I've seen it. Yeah. So it just
completely eases any anxiety I think. A
10k to go, Jenna. Almost there. Very
happy. So happy. Yeah.
Then we hit the single track where we
were told to make sure we let elite
riders pass us. That was a bit scary.
Yeah, cuz it was a single track and
there was a lot of riders back. So,
we're in the bushes for a fair bit of
that. I feel I was like, if we got to
punch it there now, we say water. Yeah,
just coming through the that last bit in

nice to have people cheering and stuff
and yeah, nice vibe. It was a really
great vibe and a really good way to
finish the day off.
Do you think you would ever come back
and do the bigger event?
Yes. you. Yeah. Yeah. Cool.
I've got neat chin.
So, our official distance was 88 km, a
little bit extra. Um 2,100 m of
climbing. Our official time was 4 hours

today. If you did, please like and

videos.curation_reason: Excellent first-person race recap with specific course details and terrain analysis from experienced coaches riding the World Championship course.

videos.title: Seven Nannup Gravel Race 2025  - UCI World Gravel Series 126km 3365vm
videos.description:
Completed my second Seven gravel race, this time on a gravel bike, aiming to break the 7-hour mark. Unfortunately, my legs werenâ€™t ready for the over-geared setup on the new  bike, which made some climbs tougher than my MTB. The extra effort led to leg cramps on long climbs, forcing me to take several breaks while I silently suffered on the side of the trailâ€”LOL. Despite the challenges, I loved the race, the stunning views, and the vibrant atmosphere. Iâ€™m already planning to return with a mullet drivetrain setup and more training to conquer it next time.

Time: 7h31m
Pace: 16.6km/h

videos.title: 2025 SEVEN GRAVEL RACE in Nannup was TOUGH!
videos.description:
My first attempt at a gravel race was a tough one! The 2025 Seven Gravel Race, part of the UCI Gravel World Series, was 125km long with around 3200m of elevation. I went out way too hard and had burnt all my matches with 50kms to go ðŸ˜…


I rode this on my Giant XTC (carbon hardtail mountain bike), and while it did the job, I might look at buying a gravel bike if I do any more of these events.

#mtb #gravel
videos.curation_reason: Personal race experience from a first-time gravel racer tackling the full 125km course, showing the race's challenging nature.

videos.title: SEVEN GRAVEL RACE 2024 | RACE HIGHLIGHTS
videos.description: How the women's elite race played out in the 2024 Edition of Seven, Australia's Premiere Gravel Race.

videos.title: My First Gravel Race -  SEVEN 2025 (FIVE 86km 2100vm) Nannup, Australia
videos.description:
After less than one year of bike riding and a nonexistent athletic career prior (except for some 5-a-side football) I thought it would be a great idea to throw my hat in the ring for one of Australia's hardest gravel events. OK OK, it might not be the full 126km 3000+ brutal climb of the full SEVEN UCI event, but the FIVE is still nothing to scoff at. It was a journey to hell and back and was definitely one of the hardest things I've done in my life. But the process of preparing and training, setting up the gear and getting out there was truly awesome and exciting. I'm even thinking about punishing myself again next year!!!!

Bike: Canyon Grizl

videos.curation_reason: Detailed first-person account of race preparation and experience from a beginner's perspective, offering valuable insights for new participants.

quotes.text: The surfaces going down were particularly sketchy. The gravel was really, really loose. Really loose. And it will just dry, which I guess makes it loose.

I'm torn between like it was clearly stunning, but I expected when I saw the 22% I was absolutely peeing, but it was actually much better than I expected. I thought there I wasn't going to get up a 22% climb.
There are over 1,600 people registered for the race tomorrow, principally because next year this will hold the world championships.

key_challenges.name: First gravel sector
key_challenges.description: Chaotic section where the surface is not always even, causing riders to come back, move forwards, and change lines. Lines disappear and you can be pushed off.

key_challenges.name: First major descent
key_challenges.description: Stretches out the peloton due to different abilities and confidence levels. Surfaces going down were particularly sketchy with really loose gravel.

key_challenges.name: Brockman climb
key_challenges.description: The first really hard climb with 22% gradient. Some riders had to push their bikes and fell off trying to climb due to losing traction.

terrain_notes.text: The gravel was really, really loose, especially on descents due to dry conditions. Makes descending feel less in control.
The gravel was really smooth in some sections and really nice to ride on, not too many ruts or bumps.
Corrugated bumps that you can get thrown into if cut off during passes.

race_day_tips.text: For the women it is so important to stay inside those front 30 wheels during the first gravel sector.
Trying to get a bit of draft is super important, especially after mechanicals.
Pick a line and stick with it on loose gravel descents - if you just go straight, you'll be fine.
The goal was to ride well, not smash ourselves, but ride to a nice pace and stay upright. The start is obviously the most chaotic part of the course.

additional_quotes.text: You can drop off your food in a bag labeled with your number and then they take it out to the halfway stop and then when you get to the halfway stop, you can find your food with the number. They'll lay it out for you there.

I would suggest if you can get in earlier to register and get a place that's closer is probably better cuz it is quite a drive even to Bustleton. It doesn't look like much on the map, but when it comes to coming all the way out here to register, it would be good to just be able to stay in the town. But you have to get in early because the accommodation does book out pretty quickly.

rider_intel.search_text: Seven gravel race in Nannup, Western Australia features 125km with 3200m of climbing and 12 categorized climbs, making it the biggest gravel race in the Southern Hemisphere. The course starts with a chaotic first gravel sector where the surface is uneven and riders get pushed off lines. Key challenges include loose, sketchy gravel on descents due to dry conditions, and the brutal Brockman climb with 22% gradients where some riders must walk. The first major descent stretches the peloton based on confidence levels. Riders emphasize staying in the front 30 wheels during early gravel sections and picking lines carefully on loose surfaces. The race offers stunning scenery through valleys with epic views, though cameras don't capture the full beauty. Over 1600 people registered, with perfect weather conditions. Course logistics include food drop bags at the halfway stop, and accommodation books out quickly requiring early registration.
